payload.name: heuristic
payload.core: Apply simple rules of thumb that often work to make fast decisions. Trade accuracy for speed when speed matters more than precision. Heuristics skip evaluation steps; they are cached decision rules, not threshold-based stopping.

out.d: explicit rule in form 'if <pattern> then <action/judgment>' with stated domain scope
evidence that current situation matches the heuristic's domain (surface feature match)
the quick decision or inference produced by rule application
low/medium/high classification with criteria (reversibility, cost of error, time pressure)
conditions under which heuristic should be abandoned for deeper analysis

proc: classify stake level: low (reversible, <$1K impact, no safety), medium (semi-reversible, <$10K), high (irreversible, >$10K or safety-critical)
recognize situation type from 2-3 surface features (not deep investigation)
retrieve applicable heuristic: state it explicitly as 'if <pattern> then <action>'
verify domain match: does current situation fall within heuristic's known-valid scope?
apply heuristic to generate candidate answer without further evaluation
check for red-flag exceptions: known failure conditions that override the heuristic
if low-stakes: accept result and document heuristic used
if medium-stakes: accept but schedule post-hoc validation sample
if high-stakes: flag for deeper analysis, do not rely on heuristic alone
quick_checklist: PRE: stake level classified before applying heuristic
PRE: heuristic stated explicitly (not implicit reasoning)
DURING: domain scope verified (situation matches heuristic's valid range)
POST: result accepted only if stakes justify shortcut
POST: sample of heuristic decisions scheduled for validation (medium stakes)
POST: heuristic logged for failure-rate tracking
check: heuristic explicitly stated in 'if-then' form, not implicit?
domain applicability verified against known scope boundaries?
time or resource constraint documented that justifies shortcut?
stake level classified and appropriate for heuristic use?
fallback to deeper analysis identified for high-stakes cases?

satisficing.boundary: satisficing evaluates candidates against a threshold; heuristic skips evaluation entirely by applying a cached rule
satisficing.test: Did you evaluate options against a threshold (satisficing) or apply a rule without evaluation (heuristic)?

fermi.boundary: Fermi decomposes into 3-7 estimable factors with bounds; heuristic applies a single cached rule without decomposition
fermi.test: Did you decompose into factors (Fermi) or apply one rule directly (heuristic)?

default-typicality.boundary: default-typicality reasons about category membership and exception blocking; heuristic is action-oriented (do X when Y)
default-typicality.test: Are you inferring properties from categories (default) or deciding actions from patterns (heuristic)?

search-based.boundary: search-based explores solution space systematically, possibly guided by heuristics; heuristic mode skips search entirely
search-based.test: Are you exploring a space (search) or short-circuiting directly to an answer (heuristic)?

debiasing.boundary: debiasing audits and corrects reasoning; heuristic embraces speed over correction
debiasing.test: Are you checking for errors (debiasing) or accepting speed tradeoffs (heuristic)?

confusions.symptom: saying 'good enough' when actually using a rule, or vice versa
confusions.resolution: satisficing requires defining a threshold and evaluating candidates until one passes; heuristic applies a rule with no candidate evaluation. If you evaluated multiple options, it was satisficing.

confusions.symptom: treating 'birds typically fly' as a heuristic
confusions.resolution: defaults reason about category membership (Tweety is a bird → Tweety flies unless exception); heuristics are action rules (if crash bug → prioritize over cosmetic). Defaults can be blocked by specificity; heuristics have red-flag overrides.

confusions.symptom: using heuristic to guide search and calling the whole process 'heuristic reasoning'
confusions.resolution: heuristics can guide search (A* uses admissible heuristics), but heuristic-as-mode means skipping search entirely. If you explored a solution space, you did search; if you jumped to an answer, you did heuristic.

fail.name: heuristics become doctrine
fail.desc: Rules of thumb ossify into unquestionable laws; original context and failure rate forgotten; exceptions dismissed rather than integrated.
signals: rules of thumb treated as universal laws (no stated domain bounds)
no exceptions permitted despite changed context
heuristic origin and rationale forgotten, only rule remembered
resistance to evidence contradicting the rule
zero heuristics retired or revised in past year
no validation sample taken for medium-stakes decisions

mitigations.mitigation: label each heuristic with explicit domain bounds
mitigations.test: can you state 3 situations where this heuristic should NOT apply?

mitigations.mitigation: track failure rate per heuristic with quarterly review
mitigations.test: is there a log showing heuristic X failed Y% of spot-checks in Q4?

mitigations.mitigation: require retirement or revision if failure rate >15%
mitigations.test: has any heuristic been retired or revised in the past year?

mitigations.mitigation: document heuristic origin and rationale when created
mitigations.test: can you explain why this heuristic was adopted and from what evidence?

mitigations.mitigation: schedule post-hoc validation sample for medium-stakes batches
mitigations.test: for the last 100 heuristic decisions, how many were spot-checked and what was the error rate?

mitigations.mitigation: pair with debiasing (mode 80) for any high-stakes decision
mitigations.test: did you run the 7-step debiasing checklist before accepting the heuristic answer for high stakes?

use: triage and initial screening (support tickets, CVEs, job applications)
guiding search in large spaces (pruning, prioritization)
high-frequency low-stakes decisions (code review focus, meeting scheduling)

rel.name: satisficing
rel.role: threshold-based stopping; heuristic skips evaluation entirely

rel.name: fermi-order-of-magnitude
rel.role: decomposition into factors; heuristic applies single cached rule

rel.name: default-typicality
rel.role: category inference with exceptions; heuristic is action-oriented

rel.name: search-based-algorithmic
rel.role: explores solution space; heuristic short-circuits to answer

rel.name: debiasing-epistemic-hygiene
rel.role: audits heuristic outputs; pair for high-stakes decisions

ex.scenario: Bug triage: 200 tickets, 2 hours to prioritize. Heuristic: 'customer-reported > internal, crash > cosmetic, recent > old'.
steps: stake classification: medium (affects sprint planning, reversible, no safety impact)
state heuristic explicitly: 'if customer-reported AND crash AND <7 days old → P1; else → backlog'
domain check: heuristic valid for product bugs; not valid for security issues (different triage)
red-flag check: any ticket mentioning 'data loss' or 'security' → escalate regardless of heuristic
apply: top 20 tickets flagged P1, remaining 180 to backlog
post-hoc validation: spot-check 5 random backlog tickets for heuristic failures
log result: heuristic applied to 200 tickets, 1/5 spot-check was misclassified (should have been P1)

micro_example.situation: Code review queue: 15 PRs, 30 minutes before standup.
micro_example.heuristic_statement: if PR <50 lines AND no API changes → quick approve; else → defer to post-standup
micro_example.domain_scope: internal tooling repo, no production traffic, all authors are trusted team members
micro_example.red_flags: changes to auth, config, or external integrations → always defer regardless of size
micro_example.stake_classification: low (internal tools, all changes reversible, no customer impact)
micro_example.application: 8 PRs match quick-approve criteria, 7 deferred. Total time: 12 minutes.
micro_example.validation: post-standup review of 2 quick-approved PRs: both appropriate, no issues
micro_example.logged_for_tracking: heuristic 'small-PR-quick-approve' used 8 times, 0 failures this week
